It seems to be an issue with mocked stdin
fix by the last commit
Would it make sense to make the same change above on line 111 ?
Maybe in the future.
Do we have to kill the frontend server? Wouldn't sending 'quit' command work more cleanly?

Yeah, `quit` is probably cleaner, but I wanted to avoid handling the case when frontend server got into some weird state - handling that would require sending `quit`, waiting with timeout for server to exit, then killing it. 

We can clean this up after we land this CL.

Arguably, if frontend server can get into weird state so that it doesn't respond to 'quit' command, we would want to know about it now. After all this is test suite that should help us uncover bugs like that.
Cleaning it up later is fine though.
Should the error messages themselves be here too?

Perhaps we can add them here later, if it would make sense to expose them like this.
Currently assumption is that complete compiler output is presented to the user which includes errors/warnings/nits.
fyi @aam

make this required to defensively avoid bugs where parameters are not passed through as required.
It would be ideal in the future to have some BuildConfig object storing all the parameters we are passing around here so there aren't any bugs flowing the args between the methods but making parameters required is the next best thing.

comments.body: Not sure why we are returning null if fileSystemRoots is null and we can't map file to package:-uri
This is a helper function wrapped by `mapFilename` and `mapFileUri`.  Returning null tells the wrapper to return the original filename or URI
has dart sdk with this flag landed in flutter?

Is it possible for a project to go from not having builders to having some while a `flutter` command is running? If so, is this case handled? IOW, would the factory be rerun to get the code-generating compiler?

Yes,  we won't be able to switch them currently. This does fall under the umbrella for "hot reload literally everything" that I am working on.

The solution is to: 1) always run with build_runner enabled and 2) use manifest invalidation as triggers to update the build script

However, that is a much bigger change. I don't think it should block letting people use the feature
Makes sense.
https://github.com/flutter/flutter/pull/29399 makes `hasBuilders` synchronous, so you don't need to `await` if you submit that PR first.
That one needs to wait on another FE server update, so I'll handle it before submitting there

comments.body: What are the trace statements for? These only show up in verbose logs
@aam
They show interaction between frontend server and compiler client.
Even if logs are are hidden we're still spending time building the strings, quite a lot in the case of the initial reload
Do you know time spent here is noticeable? I found that diagnostic to be useful, which is why I added it.
There is absolutely no reason to leave debugging code in production here
I think we frequently use `printTrace` when running in verbose mode we want to get clarity about what is going with the system to help troubleshoot issues for end users. This is no different.
Maybe it's just the directory of the output file that has to exist already?

This is also set depending on 'targetProductVm' at lines 323-324. Consider cleaning up that code.
Also, consider defining '-Ddart.vm.profile=true' depending on the mode.
Done.

This leads me to notice that we need to unify the flags used here with the flags used in `fuchsia_kernel_compiler.dart` either by keeping them in sync manually or by eliminating `fuchsia_kernel_compiler.dart` by merging its functionality into this file.

It looks like the kernel_compiler and frontend_server support a slightly different set of flags and have slightly different output behavior. Is there any reason we can't standardize on the frontend_server instead?

Ahh right. Functionality of the Fuchsia kernel compiler would need to be integrated into the frontend_server, so there's probably not much we can do right now other than manually try to keep the flags in-sync where possible.
